titleStmt.title: Mary Russell Mitford's Notebook of 1819 to 1823
titleStmt.author: Mary Russell Mitford

sponsor.orgName: Mary Russell Mitford Society: Digital Mitford Project

publicationStmt.authority: Digital Mitford: The Mary Russell Mitford Archive

availability.p: Reproduced by courtesy of the Reading Central Library.
availability.licence: Distributed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License

msDesc.p: Our source text is marked as an original carbon copy of a typed transcript of Mary Russell Mitford's notebook. From the title page of the source text: The transcript of which this is a copy is in the possession of the Public Library, Reading, Berks, England. A photostat copy of the MS is also available at that library. Copyright presumably rests with the British Museum. July 1955.
This is the location information for the autograph manuscript in Mary Russell Mitford's hand, at the British Library.

handNotes.handNote: Red crayon or thick red pencil. Annotation by an archivist on an opening page of the carbon copy of the typed transcript of Mitford's journal at Reading Central Library
Black pencil or crayon. Crosses out lines in the red crayon indicated above.
Annotation by an archivist, presumably at Reading Central Library, recording the shelfmark.
Annotation by an archivist at Reading Central Library, recording the shelfmark on the title page in light grey pencil.
Annotation by an archivist at Reading Central Library, recording the accession number.

editorialDecl.p: Mitford’s spelling and punctuation are retained, except where a word is split at the end of a line and the beginning of the next in the manuscript. Where Mitford’s spelling and hyphenation of words deviates from the standard, in order to facilitate searching we are using the TEI elements choice, sic, and reg to encode both Mitford’s spelling and the regular international standard of Oxford English spelling, following the first listed spelling in the Oxford English Dictionary. The long s and ligatured forms are not encoded.

p.add: original carbon copy of Mitford diary. pages 1-49. i.e. end of 1819

div.head:
MARY RUSSELL MITFORD
Transcript of notebook of Mary Russell Mitford
contained in the British Museum (P 24834 : C.60.b.7.)
div.p: The note-book has a printed title page The Literary Pocket-Book; or, Companion for the lover of Nature & Art, 1819. The size of the notebook is 13 x 8 cm.
Miss Mitford's notes begin on 1 January 1819 and end 11 March 1823.

The transcript of which this is a copy is in the possession of the Public Library, Reading, Berks, England. A photostat copy of the MS is also available at that library. Copyright presumably rests with the British Museum.

person.note: Amber Peddicord has sorted image files and encoded different editions of Mitford's letter manuscripts and the published versions of those letters. She is assisting the editing team in completing and checking the encoding of Mitford’s correspondence in 1822. She is currently working toward B.A.'s in English Literature and Communication at the University of Pittsburgh-Greensburg, as well as a Digital Studies Certificate. She graduates in spring 2021.

org.note: Likely includes Mr. & Mrs. W. Hayward, a brewing family connected with inns in Watlington.
The family of Jacob Newberry. Surname variously spelled Newbery and Newberry.
The family of Col. Anstruther. Associated with Reading.

person.note: Pseudonymous author of The Letters of Junius, active during the 1770s. Still unidentified, although may have been Sir Philip Francis.

Whig Member of Parliament. Strong candidate to have been Junius, the pseudonymous author of The Letters of Junius. Lord North appointed him to the Supreme Council of Bengal, which brought him into conflict with Governor-General Warren Hastings. Leading proponent of Hastings's impeachment. Supporter of the French Revolution and Parliamentary reform.

Son of a wine merchant of Irish descent who made his fortune in Portugal, his family emigrated to England and he joined the British army as a young man. Translator of Portuguese literature. Spouse of Dora Wordsworth.
Author of books for children, including a True Stories series on historical and biographical subjects. Signed her works M.E.B. and A Mother.
Author of biographical sketches of contributors to The Spectator as well as a biography of Edmund Burke
Attended Reading School at the same time as Talfourd. Newspaper and magazine editor and writer, he authored a multi-volume parody of contemporary authors, Warreniana.

Artist and antiquarian who collected and illustrated historical costume, arms, seals, and other objects of cultural interest from English history. Author of Biographical Dictionary of Engravers, Dresses and Habits of the English People, Sports and Pastimes of the People of England and Queenhoo Hall.

Important figure in Jena Romanticism, the first wave of German Romantic literature and philosophy. An early scholar of comparative historical linguistics. Mitford read his Lectures on the History of Literature: Ancient and Modern.

person.persName: Félix Lope de Vega y Carpio
person.note: Prolific and renowned Spanish writer of the Baroque period, active from 1580 into the 17th century. Important playwright whose works were translated and adapted for English theater from 1660. He
Anglo-Irish writer and political figure, Mamber of Parliament and of the Privy Council of Ireland.

Hoare took several tours to continental Europe as well as to Ireland, Wales, and the Island of Elba, which formed the basis of his sketches and later book publications. With William Cunnington, he made the first recorded excavations at Stonehenge in 1798 and in 1810. He also excavated 379 barrows on Salisbury Plain. He extensively studied the history and archaeology of Wiltshire, the county in which his estate was located, and in 1786 he purchased Glastonbury Tor, in Somerset, in order to study and preserve it.

Daughter of John Aikin and niece of Anna Laetitia Barbauld. Prolific author of verse and prose for children, including two textbooks, as well as biographies of European historical figures for adults. Under her pseudonym, she authored several groundbreaking abridgements of British novels and stories, starting with Robinson Crusoe in Words of One Syllable. Like Mitford, she was also known as a witty and intelligent letter writer.
Author of 11 novels between the 1810s and 1830s. Friend of Anna Maria and Jane Porter. After her retirement from writing, she kept a small shop in Cheshire.

Author of poetry for children and historical novels for adults. She contributed to Original Poems for Infant Minds with Jane Taylor. Daughter of John O'Keeffe, she supported him financially and assisted with his writing. Mitford read her contemporary novel Dudley.
Daughter of Rev. Henry Moncrieff-Wellwood and spouse of Sir John Stoddart. Authored works for children, set in her native Scotland, under the pseudonym Martha Blackford.

Expert on Roman sculpture and other antiquities of the ancient world. With his father, art conservator and cataloguer of the Roman antiquities owned by the Vatican in the 1780s. In the 1790s, he also published catalogs of Richard Worsley's Greek antiquities and of the sculptures in the Villa Borghese. Emigrated to Paris, where he became curator of Napoleon's collections at the Louvre and a professor of archaeology. Published 7 volumes of Greek and Roman ancient world portraits, in French. One of the experts consulted on the Elgin marbles. He believed that Roman sculptures did not imitate but improved upon the works of the Greeks.
Mentored by Edmund Burke and friend of Scott and Wordsworth
Proponent of Whig causes such as the abolition of the slave trade. Wrote for the Edinburgh Review as well as authoring longer works on political and literary history.
bookseller author editor publisher
newspaper prop.
legal journalist
politician planter
Son of Mr. Liebensrood
Surname also spelled MacDonough.

person.persName: Prince Edward, Duke of Kent and Strathearn
person.note: 4th son of King George III, his daughter became Queen Victoria, following the 1817 death of Princess Charlotte, the royal family's only other legitimate grandchild. Served as a British army officer in Quebec and Halifax in the 1790s and played an influential role in the UK's changing relations with Upper and Lower Canada and with the United States. From 1799, he served as Commander-in-Chief of British forces in North America. Also served with the rank of Field Marshal in the French Revolutionary and Coalition (Napoleonic) Wars. He died of pneumonia and Mitford dons mourning dress for him.
M. P.

person.persName: Pierre Alexandre Edouard Fleury de Chaboulon

person.note: M.D. and Professor of Moral Philosophy at the University of Edinburgh.
Cook Mitford hired in Reading for Bertram House on February 13, 1819. Works for about a year, as another Cook is hired on March 14, 1820. Name unknown. Dates unknown.

Cook Mitford hired Reading for Bertram House on March 14, 1820. She is employed for about a week, then resigns or is fired, as another Cook is hired on March 21. Mrs. Hudswell tells her about their old Cook's misconduct, as reported in the Journal on March 14, 1820. Name unknown. Dates unknown.
Cook Mitford hired Readingfor Bertram House, ahead of their move to Three Mile Cross on March 21, 1820. Name unknown. Dates unknown.
knew Byron, Vicar of Harrow

person.persName: Marie-Thérèse Charlotte de France, Duchesse d'Angloulême

person.note: One of Mitford's greyhounds at Bertram House in 1819.
Female dog given as a gift to MRM bby Farmer Webb in February 1819 and married to MRM's dog Mossy in May 1819.
Associated with Watlington

Benjamin Robert Haydon was a painter educated at the Royal Academy, who was famous for contemporary, historical, classical, biblical, and mythological scenes, though tormented by financial difficulties and incarceration. He painted William Wordsworth's portrait in 1842 and painted a cameo of Keats in his epic canvas Christ's Entry into Jerusalem(1814-20). MRM was introduced to him at his London studio in the spring of 1817, and Sir William Elford was a mutual friend, and Haydon’s own acquaintances included several prominent British Romantic literary figures. He completed The Raising of Lazarus in 1823. He wrote a diary and an autobiography, both of which were published only posthumously, and he committed suicide in 1846. George Paston's Little Memoirs of the Nineteenth Century (1893) contends that Mitford was asked to edit Haydon's memoir, but declined.

place.note: Mr. Dearesley's copse near Bertram House. Mitford went primrosing there in March 1819. Source: Journal.
House belonging to Richard Body in Three Mile Cross where Mary Russell Mitford moved with her parents in 1820 after leaving Bertram House. Mitford lived there until 1851.
Fields at Burghfield Bridge. George Mitford went there to get his daughter Field Tulips in April 1819.
Fields belonging to the Bertram House estate. One location where Mitford goes violetting in March 1819. Some of the fields are used for haying.
Plantations--planted woodlands--belonging to the Bertram House estate. One location where Mitford went firtopping and fed my robins in winter 1819 and 1820,
Fields belonging to the ichard Body. One location where Mitford goes violetting in March 1819.
Field belonging to the Mr. Dearsley, once part of the Bertram House estate, sold by George Mitford. One location where Mitford goes violetting in March 1819.
Field belonging to Mr. Pithers. One location where Mitford goes violetting in March 1819, although she did not find any that year.
Frequent destination for Mitford walks and drives, accompanied by Lucy & their dogs. Frequent site for collecting flower, including violets, pansies, cowslips, and wood sorrel.
Fields near the cottage at Three Mile Cross.
Garden at Bertram House estate.
Meadows belonging to the Bertram House estate.
Meadows owned by Mr. Bridgewater. One of the locations Mitford goes cowslipping in April 1820.
Meadows owned by Mr. Davies. One of the locations Mitford goes to gather woodsorrel and violets.
Meadows near the cottage at Three Mile Cross.
One of the houses Mitfords view but do not choose in planning their relocation from Bertram Housein 1820.
In Mitford's time, the Ashmolean collection was housed in the 1683 Old Ashmolean, a purpose-built museum on Broad Street that now houses Oxford's History of Science Museum.
Hamlet near Reading named after a bridge crossing the River Kennett. The existing bridge was constructed in 1812 and is a Grade II listed building.
Small parish that runs from Ilsley Downs to the Vale of White Horse district; historically part of Berkshire and now in Oxfordshire.

Large parish. In 1831, the Hundred of Overton contained Ashe, Bradley, Deane, Laverstoke, Overton, Tadley, and North Waltham. Overton Mill has produced banknote paper since the eighteenth century. Richard Russell lived here as vicar of Overton and rector of Ashe and Deane.
Hamlet near Reading.

Small market town on the edge of the Chiltern Hills. By the late eighteenth century, it had six inns, all owned by the Hayward brewing family. Watlington Town Hall, built in 1665, is a Grade II listed building.

listBibl.bibl: The Pamphleteer London A. J. Valpy Published between 1813 and 1828. Full title: The Pamphleteer: Respectfully Dedicated to Both Houses of Parliament. To be Continued Occasionally, an Average of Four or Five Numbers Annually. Contained shorthand reportage of major Parliamentary speeches, as well as original and reprinted pamphlets, reports, essays, and letters on current political and economic, as well as social, literary and medical issues. Contributors included Sir William Elford, Thomas Noon Talfourd and John Sinclair, among others. Special topics of particular interest to Mitford and her circle included copyright law, the laws regulating theatres, greyhounds and coursing, and brewing. xvvv

bibl.title: British Critic
bibl.note: Tory periodical

bibl.title: Eclectic Review
bibl.note: Periodical

bibl.title: the Monthly Magazine
bibl.note: Periodical

bibl.title: European Magazine
bibl.note: Periodical

bibl.title: Edinburgh Review
bibl.note: Periodical

bibl.title: Edinburgh Magazine; or Literary Miscellany
bibl.note: Published by Sibbald, 1785 to 1816, then published by Constable until 1826.

bibl.title: Edinburgh Magazine; or Literary Miscellany
bibl.note: Previously published by Sibbald, then published by Constable, 1817 to 1826.

bibl.title: Three Months Passed in the Mountains East of Rome: during the year 1819
bibl.author: Maria Graham
bibl.publisher: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, and Brown
bibl.note: Illustrated with engravings. Source: Google Books and WorldCAT. Mitford mentions this book in her Journal entry of August 29, 1820 and rated it not good.

bibl.title: Two Papers: A Theatrical Critique, and an Essay [ . . . ] attributed to the Editor of the Ex-m-n-r
bibl.note: Satire aimed at Leigh Hunt. Full title: Two Papers: A Theatrical Critique, and an Essay (being No. 999 of the Pretender on Sonnet-writing and Sonnet-writers in general, including A Sonnet on Myself, attributed to the Editor of the Examiner, and preceded by Proofs of their Authenticity, founded upon the authority of internal evidence.

bibl.title: Florence Macarthy: An Irish Tale
bibl.note: Mitford records that she was very much amused by it. Later, she writes that she liked it better than the first, perhaps comparing the last volume to the first. Source: Journal entry Saturday 23 JANUARY 1819

bibl.title: Remarks on Antiquities, Arts, and Letters, During an Excursion in Italy, in the Years 1802 and 1803.
bibl.author: Joseph Forsyth
bibl.note: Mitford records she was charmed with it in her journal entry of Monday 15 February 1819.

bibl.title: Marriage: A Novel
bibl.author: Susan Ferrier
bibl.note: Mitford records that she liked it very much; she also says that it made me laugh. In journal entry Saturday 13 MARCH 1819.

bibl.title: Women: Or Pour et Contre. A Tale
bibl.note: Mitford records that she liked it very much; she also says that it made me laugh.In Journal Saturday 27 MARCH 1819.

bibl.title: The Monks and the Giants: Prospectus and Specimen of an Intended National Work; Intended to Comprise the Most Interesting Particulars Relating to King Arthur and his Round Table, by William and Robert Whistlecraft of Stow-Market, in Suffolk, Harness and Collar Makers
bibl.author: John Hookham Frere
bibl.note: An ottava rima burlesque written by John Hookham Frere under the nom de plume William and Robert Whistlecraft. Sources: LBT, ODNB
Mitford rated it very good.In journal entry Thursday 15 APRIL 1819.

bibl.author: Miss Tully
bibl.title: A Narrative of a Ten Years’ Residence at Tripoli in Africa from the Original Correspondence in the Possession of the Family of the Late Richard Tully, Esq., Comprising Authentic Memoirs and Anecdotes of the Reigning Bashaw, His Family, and Other Persons of Distinction; also an Account of the Domestic Manners of the Moors, Arabs, and Turks
bibl.note: Mitford may have read the third edition, published in 1819.
Mitford rated it very entertaining indeed. In journal entry Wednesday 12 MAY 1819.

bibl.title: Wheel of Fortune
bibl.note: Play first performed in 1795 and printed 1805.
Mitford rated it middling. In journal entrySunday 16 MAY 1819.

bibl.title: Don Juan
bibl.note: Published in parts between 1820 and 1824.
Mitford rated it good but wicked. In journal entry Saturday 31 JULY 1819

bibl.title: Peter’s Letters to his Kinsfolk

author.note: A fictious first edition was advertised in Blackwood’s, and the first printed edition was labeled second edition on the title page, although it was actually the first edition. Published anonymously.

bibl.note: Mitford rated it very good. In journal entry Saturday 4 SEPTEMBER 1819

bibl.title: Some Account of the Life of Rachael Wriothesley, Lady Russell, by the editor of Madam Du Deffand’s letters. Followed by a series of letters from Lady Russell to her husband, William, Lord Russell; from 1672 to 1682; together with some miscellaneous letters to and from Lady Russell. To which are added, eleven letters from Dorothy Sidney, Countess of Sunderland, to George Saville, Marquis of Hallifax, in the year 1680
The Life of Lady Russell
bibl.author: Rachael Wriothesley, Lady Russell
Dorothy Sidney, Countess of Sunderland
bibl.publisher: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme and Brown
bibl.note: Source: HathiTrust
Mitford rated it interesting. In journal entry Tuesday 5 OCTOBER 1819

bibl.title: The Poetical Remains of the Late Dr. John Leyden, with Memoirs of his Life, by the Rev. James Morton.
The Poetical Remains of Dr. Leyden
bibl.author: John Leyden
James Morton
bibl.publisher: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme and Brown
bibl.note: Source: HathiTrust
Mitford rated it very good. In journal entry Thursday 14 OCTOBER 1819

bibl.title: Shakespeare and His Times: Including the Biography of the Poet; Criticisms on his Genius and Writings; A New Chronology of the Plays; A Disquisition on the Object of His Sonnets; And a History of the Manners, Customs, and Amusements, Superstitions, Poetry, and Elegant Literature of His Age
bibl.author: Nathan Drake
bibl.note: Mitford considered it good materials badly used. In journal entry Sunday 19th March 1820
As Mitford reads, she rates it not very good, not so good as some of his Novels and then, presumably as she reads the final volume, pretty good too. In journal entry Friday 7th April 1820

bibl.title: Letters from the Hon. Horace Walpole to George Montagu, Esq. from the year 1736, to the year 1770: Now First Published from the Originals in the Possession of the Editor
bibl.publisher: Rodwell and Martin, and H. Colburn
bibl.note: A second edition appears in 1819.
Mitford rated it charming. In journal entry Friday 12 NOVEMBER 1819

bibl.title: Hacho; or, the Spell of St. Wilten
bibl.note: Narrative poem in imitation of Scott, written while the author was at Cambridge.
Mitford rated it tolerable. In journal entry Friday 11th February 1820

bibl.title: The Man in the Moon
bibl.note: Full title: The Man in the Moon, A Speech from the Throne to the Senate of Lunataria. In the Moon.. Political satire.

bibl.title: Account of the captivity of Capt. Robert Knox and other Englishmen, in the island of Ceylon
bibl.note: Full title: Account of the Captivity of Capt. Robert Knox and other Englishmen, in the island of Ceylon; and of the Captain's miraculous escape, and return to England, in September, 1680; after detention on the island of nineteen years and a half..

bibl.title: Memoirs of the Most Renowned James Graham, Marquis of Montrose
bibl.note: Full title: Memoirs of the most renowned James Graham, Marquis of Montrose. Translated from the Latin of the Rev. Dr. George Wishart, afterwards Bishop of Edinburgh. To which are added, sundry original letters, never before published. After reading, Mitford commented that Graham was a very great man & great poet!.

bibl.title: Mordaunt: Sketches of Life, Characters, and Manners, in Various Countries
bibl.note: Full title: Mordaunt: Sketches of Life, Characters, and Manners, in Various Countries; including the Memoirs of a French Lady of Quality.. Mitford rated it an excellent old Novel.

bibl.title: The Sacrifice Of Isabel: A Poem.
bibl.publisher: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, and Brown
bibl.note: Mitford rated it. an elegant Poem.

bibl.title: Manuscript sermons
bibl.note: Unpublished manuscript sermons by Mitford's grandfather. Mitford owns a copy, which she loans to Charles Knyvett.

bibl.title: Manuscript tribute to Mossy
bibl.note: Manuscript tribute to Mossy, written after his death.

bibl.title: Manuscript poem to Mossy
bibl.note: Manuscript poem to Mossy, written after his death.

bibl.title: Independence
bibl.note: Author and date unidentified.

bibl.title: Authentic Account of the French Revolution
bibl.note: Author and date unidentified. Mitford rated it interesting. Source: Journal.

bibl.note: Author and date unidentified.

bibl.note: Author and date unidentified.

bibl.note: Author and date unidentified. Mitford rated it pretty good.

bibl.note: Author and date unidentified.

bibl.note: Author and date unidentified.

bibl.title: Vicissitudes
bibl.note: Author and date unidentified.

By the late John Opie, Esq. Professor in Painting at the Royal Academy. To which are prefixed, a memoir by Mrs. Opie, and other accounts of Mr. Opie's talents and character.

bibl.note: Full title: The Critical and Miscellaneous Prose Works of John Dryden, Now First Collected: with Notes and Illustrations; An Account of the Life and Writings of the Author, Grounded on Original and Authentick Documents; and A Collection of His Letters, the greater part of which has never before been published..

bibl.title: The Italian
bibl.publisher: T. Cadell, Jr. and W. Davies
bibl.note: Full title: The Italian, or the Confessional of the Black Penitents. A Romance.

bibl.title: The Original of the Miniature. a Novel.
bibl.note: 4 volumes. Printed at the Minerva Press.

bibl.title: Queenhoo Hall, A Romance
bibl.note: 3 volumes. Published with Ancient Times, a drama (vol. 4).

bibl.title: View of the State of Europe during the Middle Ages
bibl.note: 3 volumes. Mitford rated it good

bibl.title: Report of the Action, Wright v. Clement
bibl.note: Full title: Report of the Action, Wright v. Clement: for certain libels published in Cobbett's Political Register: tried in the Court of King's Bench at Westminster, on Friday, the 10th of December, 1819, before Lord Chief Justice Abbott and a special jury.

bibl.title: A Descriptive Catalogue of the Pictures in the Royal Museum, or, the Louvre
bibl.note: Full title: A Descriptive Catalogue of the Pictures in the Royal Museum, or, the Louvre; also, A description of the sculpture in the lower gallery.

bibl.title: History of the West Indies
bibl.note: 5 volumes. Full title: The History, Civil and Commercial, of the British West Indies. with a continuation to the present time. with maps and plates.

bibl.title: The Life of Wesley
bibl.publisher: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, and Brown
bibl.note: 2 volumes. Full title: The Life of Wesley; and the Rise and Progress of Methodism. Mitford rated it very good.

bibl.title: A Circumstantial Narrative of the Campaign in Saxony, in the year 1813
bibl.note: Full title: A Circumstantial Narrative of the Campaign in Saxony, in the year 1813; written originally in German by Baron von Odeleben, [...] To which are subjoined the notes of M. Aubert de Vitry, editor of the French edition. The whole translated by A. J. Kempe. Mitford rated it good.

bibl.title: Dudley
bibl.publisher: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, and Brown
bibl.note: 3 volumes. by Miss O'Keeffe.

bibl.title: The Eskdale Herd-Boy
bibl.publisher: T. Cadell, Jr. and W. Davies
bibl.note: Full title: The Eskdale Herd-Boy, a Scottish Tale for the Instruction and Amusement of Young People. Mitford rated it good.

bibl.title: Speeches in Parliament of the Right Honourable William Windham
bibl.publisher: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme and Brown
bibl.note: 3 volumes. Full title: Speeches in Parliament of the Right Honourable William Windham, to which is prefixed some account of his life by Thomas Amyot. Mitford rated them good and very good.

bibl.title: Tales of Fancy: The Shipwreck
bibl.note: The Shipwreck makes up volume one of the three-volume work. The remaining volumes make up Country Neighbours. As she reads, Mitford rated it famous; very good and very good indeed.

bibl.title: Tales of Fancy: Country Neighbors; or, The Secret
Delphine
bibl.note: Mitford rated it not good and much too dismal.

bibl.title: Travels in Nubia
bibl.note: Published by the Association for Promoting the Discovery for the Interior Parts of Africa.

bibl.title: Mission from Cape Coast Castle to Ashantee
bibl.note: Full title: Mission from Cape Coast Castle to Ashantee: with a statistical account of that Kingdom, and geographical notices of other parts of the interior of Africa. Mitford rated it dull.

bibl.title: Memoirs of Richard Lovell Edgeworth
bibl.note: 2 volumes. Full title: Memoirs of Richard Lovell Edgeworth, Esq. begun by himself and concluded by his daughter, Maria Edgeworth. Mitford rated it very good.

bibl.title: Travels in the North of Germany
bibl.note: Full title: Travels in the North of Germany: Describing the Present State of the Social and Political Institutions [. . . ] Particularly in the Kingdom of Hanover. Mitford rates it as good politics but middling writing.

bibl.title: Knights of the Swan
bibl.note: 2 volumes. Full title: The Knights of the Swan: or, the court of Charlemagne: a romance, written by the Countess of Genlis, in continuation of The tales of the castle.

bibl.title: Walsingham
bibl.note: Full title: Walsingham, or the Pupil of Nature: A Domestic Story. Reprinted in 1805 by William Lane for Minerva Press. Mitford rated it old & bad.

bibl.title: King Coal's Levée
bibl.publisher: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, and Brown
bibl.note: Full title: King Coal's Levee, Or Geological Etiquette, With Explanatory Notes; And The Council Of The Metals. Mitford called it a pretty little thing.

bibl.title: Memoirs of Frederica Sophia Wilhelmina
bibl.note: Full title: Memoirs of Frederica Sophia Wilhelmina: princess royal of Prussia, margravine of Bareith, sister of Frederick the Great. Manuscripts show that her memoirs were written or revised in French between 1748 and 1758, and then printed in German and in French in 1810.

bibl.title: The Hermit in London
bibl.note: Published anonymously. 5 volumes. Full title: The Hermit In London, Or, Sketches of English Manners. Mitford rated it very good.

bibl.title: A Sketch of my Friend's Family
bibl.note: Full title: A Sketch of my Friend's Family: intended to suggest some practical hints on religion and domestic manners. Mitford rated it sad Methodistical stuff.

bibl.title: Sir Philip Francis denied!: a letter addressed to the British nation
bibl.note: James Wilmot's niece Olivia Wilmot Serres claims that her uncle wrote The Letters of Junius. Part of the controversy over the identity of the pseudonymous author.

bibl.title: The Letters of Junius
bibl.note: Collection of letters written pseudonymously between 1769 and 1772 and colleccted by newspaper editor Henry Woodfall in 1772. Political polemic critical of the government and of George III. In 1770, Woodfall was prosecuted for seditious libel and acquitted over printing a portion of the letters, which appeared in The Public Advertiser. The author was never identified and scholars' current thinking attributes the work to Sir Philip Francis. The controversy over authorship was still lively in Mitford's day and throughout the 19th century. Mitford called its contents a famous peppering and says that there is nothing so good now.

bibl.title: Lectures on the English Poets, delivered at the Surrey Institution
Narrative of a Journey in Egypt and the Country Beyond the Cataracts
Harold the Exile
bibl.author: anonymous
bibl.note: 3 volumes. Published anonymously and with no publisher listed. Considered to be a fictionalized account of the early life of Byron and his spouse Annabelle Millbank Byron. Mitford rated it very stupid & dismal.

bibl.title: Antiquitates Curiosae: the etymology of many remarkable old sayings, proverbs, & singular customs
The Way to Keep Him. A Comedy in Five Acts
bibl.note: Full title: The Way to Keep Him: a Comedy in five acts, as it is performed at the Theatre-Royal in Drury-Lane. An earlier 1760 version had 3 acts, rather than 5.

bibl.title: Napoleon Peint Par Lui-même. Extraits du Véritable Manuscrit de Napoleon Bonaparte, par un Amércain
Traits of Nature
bibl.note: 5 volumes.

bibl.title: Mazeppa, a Poem.
bibl.note: Mitford records that she liked it very much.

bibl.title: The Literary Works of Sir Joshua Reynolds
bibl.note: Full title: The Literary Works Of Sir Joshua Reynolds, Knight. Late President Of The Royal Academy; Containing His Discourses, Papers In The Idler, The Journal Of A Tour Through Flanders And Holland, And Also His Commentary On Du Fresnoy's Art Of Painting. Printed From The Author's Revised Copies, With his last Corrections and Additions: To Which Is Prefixed, Some Account of the Life of the Author By Edmond Malone, Esq. In Three Volumes.

bibl.title: Memoirs of the Court of Elizabeth, Queen of England
bibl.publisher: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, Brown, and Green
bibl.note: 2 volumes.

bibl.title: Manners: A Novel
bibl.note: 3 vols. Written under the pseudonym Madame Panache. Mitford rated it a pretty thing.

bibl.title: Tales of my Landlord, 3rd series
bibl.publisher: T. Cadell, Jr. and W. Davies
bibl.note: 4 volumes. The Bride of Lammermoor made up volumes one and two and Legend of Montrose, volumes three and four.

bibl.title: A Classical Tour Through Italy and Sicily
bibl.note: Full title: A Classical Tour Through Italy and Sicily: tending to illustrate some districts which have not been described by Mr. Eustace. Mitford dismissed it as humdrum.

bibl.title: The Insane World
bibl.note: Full title: The Insane World; or, a Week in London. A Satire. Mitford dismissed it as stupid and frantical.

bibl.title: An Account of Denmark in 1692
bibl.note: Full title: An Account of Denmark as it was in the year MDCXCII.

bibl.title: Remarks on the History of England
bibl.note: Full title: Remarks on the History of England: From the Minutes of Humphry Oldcastle, Esq. Published pseudonymously as Humphry Oldcastle. She rated them famous. Mitford may have read the later reprint published by T. Davies.

bibl.title: Account of the War in Spain and Portugal, and in the South of France, from 1808, to 1814, inclusive
bibl.note: She rated considered it a sad uncandid military book

bibl.title: The Works of Jonathan Richardson
bibl.note: Full title: The Works of Mr. Jonathan Richardson. Consisting of I. The theory of painting. II. Essay on the art of criticism, so far as it relates to painting. III. The science of a connoisseur.

bibl.title: A Collection of Political Tracts
bibl.note: Full title: A Collection of Political Tracts: By the author of the Dissertation upon Parties. She rated them famous. Mitford may have read the later reprint published by T. Davies.

bibl.title: Tales of the Hall
bibl.note: 2 vols. Verse. Last work published in his lifetime.

bibl.title: Journal of a Route Across India
bibl.note: Full title: Journal of a Route Across India, Through Egypt, to England, in the Latter End of the Year 1817, and the Beginning of 1818.

bibl.title: A Description of the Colony of New South Wales
bibl.note: Full title: A Statistical, Historical, and Political Description of the Colony of New South Wales, and its Dependent Settlements in Van Diemen's Land. Mitford rated it not good.

bibl.title: The Miser Married: A Novel
bibl.publisher: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, and Brown
bibl.note: 3 volumes. Mitford rated it a clever thing.

bibl.title: The Life of William, Lord Russell
bibl.publisher: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme and Brown

bibl.title: Lectures on the History of Literature: Ancient and Modern
The Young Philosopher. A Novel
bibl.publisher: T. Cadell, Jr. and W. Davies
bibl.note: Mitford rated it pretty but too dismal. Source: Journal.

bibl.title: The Life and Reign of King Richard the Second, by a Person of Quality
Historical Account of Discoveries and Travels in Africa, by the late J. Leyden
bibl.note: Full title: Historical Account of Discoveries and Travels in Africa, by the late J. Leyden, enlarged and completed to the present time, with illustrations.

bibl.title: Mémoires pour servir à l'histoire de la vie privée, du retour, et du règne de Napoléon en 1815
bibl.note: Mitford rated it rather dull but then also called it a most interesting book.

bibl.title: The Works of the Right Honourable Lord Byron. Vol. 6 of 6
bibl.note: Full title: The Works of the Right Honourable Lord Byron. In Six Volumes. Vol. VI: Prisoner of Chillon, Manfred, Lament of Tasso, &c..

bibl.title: Prisoner of Chillon
Lament of Tasso
Pétrarque et Laura
The Pilgrim of the Cross
bibl.note: 4 vols. Full title: The Pilgrim of the Cross: or, the Chronicles of Christabelle de Mowbray; an Ancient Legend.

bibl.title: Narrative of a Voyage to Senegal in 1816
bibl.note: Full title: Narrative of a Voyage to Senegal in 1816; Undertaken by Order of the French Government, Comprising an Account of the Shipwreck of the Medusa, the Sufferings of the Crew, and the Various Occurrences on Board the Raft, in the Desert of Zaara, at St. Louis, and at the Camp of Daccard. To Which are Subjoined Observations Respecting the Agriculture of the Western Coast of Africa, from Cape Blanco to the Mouth of the Gambia. Mitford rated it horrible.

bibl.title: Illustrations of the Literary History of the Eighteenth Century
bibl.note: Full title: Illustrations of the Literary History of the Eighteenth Century, Consisting of Authentic Memoirs and Original Letters of Eminent Persons; and Intended as a Sequel to The Literary Anecdotes. Mitford rated it variously as very amusing and amusing enough.

bibl.title: Percival: or, Nature Vindicated: a Novel.
bibl.note: Mitford called it a stupid old Novel. Source: Journal.

bibl.title: Remarks on Scepticism
bibl.note: Full title: Remarks on Scepticism especially as it is connected with the subjects of organization and life. Being an answer to the views of M. Bichat, Sir T.C. Morgan, and Mr. Lawrence upon those points.

bibl.title: Cursory Observations upon the Lectures on Physiology, Zoology, and the Natural History of Man
bibl.note: Full title: Cursory Observations upon the Lectures on Physiology, Zoology, and the Natural History of Man, delivered at the Royal College of Surgeons, by W. Lawrence. In a series of letters addressed to that gentleman; with a concluding letter to his pupils. To which is added, a congratulatory address to Mr. Lawrence on the suppression of his Lectures 2nd edition. Ed. Edward William Grinfield. James Wheeler loaned the book to Mitford. She rated it famous.

bibl.title: Greenland: being extracts from a journal kept in that country in the years 1770 to 1778
bibl.note: Full title: Greenland: being extracts from a journal kept in that country in the years 1770 to 1778: to which is prefixed, an introduction; containing some accounts of the manners of the Greenlanders, and of the mission in Greenland

bibl.title: Bishop Burnet's History of his Own Time
bibl.note: Full title: Bishop Burnet's History of his Own Time from the restoration of King Charles II to the conclusion of the treaty of peace at Utrecht, in the reign of Queen Anne. To which is prefixed, a summary recapitualtion of affairs in Church and State, from King James I to the restoration in the year 1660, together with the author's life.

bibl.title: The Diary of an Invalid
bibl.note: Full title: The Diary of an Invalid; being the journal of a tour in pursuit of health in Portugal, Italy, Switzerland, and France in the years 1817, 1818, and 1819. Mitford rated it famous.

bibl.title: Memoirs of the First Thirty-two Years of the Life of James Hardy Vaux
bibl.note: 2 vols. Full title: Volume 1: Memoirs of the First Thirty-two Years of the Life of James Hardy Vaux, a swindler and pickpocket: now transported, for the second time, and for life, to New South Wales and volume 2: Memoirs of James Hardy Vaux.

bibl.title: Leighton Priory
bibl.note: Author and date unidentified.

bibl.title: The Mysterious Wife: a novel
bibl.note: 4 volumes. Minerva Press. Published under the pseudonym Gabrielli.

bibl.title: Thaddeus of Warsaw
Memoirs, Illustrative of the Life and Writing of John Evelyn
bibl.note: Full title: Memoirs, Illustrative of the Life and Writings of John Evelyn, Esq. F.R.S. author of the Sylva, &c. &c.: comprising his diary, from the year 1641 to 1705-6, and a selection of his familiar letters: to which is subjoined, the private correspondence between King Charles I and his Secretary of State, Sir Edward Nicholas, whilst his majesty was in Scotland, 1641, and at other times during the Civil War: also between Sir Edward Hyde, afterwards Earl of Clarendon, and Sir Richard Browne, ambassador to the Court of France, in the time of King Charles I and the usurpation: the whole now first published from the original mss. in two volumes. Mitford rated it as very entertaining.

bibl.title: Memoirs of the Private Life of my Father
bibl.note: Full title: Memoirs of the Private Life of my Father. To which are added miscellanies by M. Necker. Translated from the French..

bibl.title: The History of the Parisian Massacre
bibl.note: Full title: The History of the Parisian Massacre; Wherein all the minute circumstances of that sanguinary event are faithfully pourtrayed: collected from unpublished manuscripts, impartial historic writers, and other authentic sources.. Mitford rated it bad.

bibl.title: An Autumn Near the Rhine
bibl.publisher: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, and Brown
bibl.note: Full title: An Autumn Near the Rhine; Or Sketches of Courts, Society, Scenery, &c. in Some of the German States Bordering on the Rhine.

bibl.title: De Rancé: a Poem
Zuma, or the Tree of Health
bibl.note: Full title: Zuma, or the Tree of Health. To which are added, the fair Pauline,--Zeneida,--the reeds of the Tiber,--and the Widow of Luzi. First published in Paris in 1817 asZuma, ou, La Découverte du quinquina uivi de La belle Paule, de Zenéide, des Roseaux du Tibre, etc. Mitford dismisses it as stupid.

bibl.title: A Narrative of the Expedition to Algiers in the Year 1816
bibl.note: Full title: A Narrative of the Expedition to Algiers in the Year 1816, under the command of the right hon. Admiral Lord Viscount Exmouth. Mitford rated it good.

bibl.title: A Journal of a Soldier of the 71st
bibl.note: Full title: A Journal of a Soldier of the 71st, or Glasgow Regiment, Highland Light Infantry, from 1806 to 1815. Mitford called it as stupid enough.

bibl.title: Headlong Hall
bibl.note: Mitford rated it as famous.

bibl.title: Italian Translations
bibl.note: Unpublished manuscript translations of works in Italian. Mitford reviewed the manuscript proofs.

bibl.title: The Sicilian
bibl.note: Minerva Press.

bibl.title: Winter Evening's Tales
bibl.note: 2 vols. Full title: Winter Evening's Tales, collected among the cottagers in the South of Scotland.

bibl.title: Tales of Wonder, of Humour, and of Sentiment; Original and Translated
bibl.note: 2 vols. Volume 1 contains Zelis, The Weathercock, The Magic Dollar Volume 2 contains The Spectre of Presburg, The Fair of Beaucaire, Tsching-Quang. Mitford rates it very amusing.

bibl.title: Letters from the Continent

publisher.orgName: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, and Brown

bibl.note: Full title: Letters from the Continent During the Months of October, November, and December, 1818: Including a Visit to Aix-la-Chapelle, and the Left Bank of the Rhine.

bibl.title: A Voyage up the Persian Gulf, and a Journey Overland from India to England, in 1817

publisher.orgName: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, and Brown

bibl.title: The Beggar Girl and her Benefactors
bibl.note: 5 vols. Minerva Press. Mitford rated it as famous.

bibl.title: A Walk Through Switzerland in September 1816
An Interesting Narrative of the Travels of James Bruce, Esq. into Abyssinia
bibl.note: Full title: An Interesting Narrative of the Travels of James Bruce, Esq. into Abyssinia: To discover the source of the Nile. Abridged from the original work. Mitford rated it very learned & curious.

bibl.title: The History of the Crusades

publisher.orgName: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, and Brown

bibl.note: Full title: The History of the Crusades, for the recovery and possession of the Holy Land. Mitford rated it very good.

bibl.title: Political and Literary Anecdotes of his Own Times
A Tour to Alet and La Grande Chartreuse
bibl.note: Full title: A Tour to Alet and La Grande Chartreuse by Dom Claude Lancelot, Author of the Port Royal Grammar, with some account of the monastery and abbot reformer of La Trappe; also, biographical sketches of M. Du Verger de Hauranne, Abbé St. Cyran, Cornelius Jansenius, bishop of Ypres; and a brief view of the celebrated institution of Port Royal.

bibl.title: Criminal Trials Illustrative of the Tale Entitled The Heart of Mid-Lothian
bibl.note: Full title: Criminal Trials Illustrative of the Tale Entitled The Heart of Mid-Lothian: published from the original record, with a prefatory notice, including some particulars of the life of Capt. John Porteous..

bibl.title: Peter Bell. A Lyrical Ballad.
bibl.note: Parodic work, purporting to be by Wordsworth. Mitford reports that she liked it and the original very much. Source: Journal entry Friday 11 JUNE 1819

bibl.title: Peter Bell. A Tale in Verse.
bibl.note: Mitford reports that she liked it and the parody by J. H. Reynolds very much. Source: Journal.

bibl.title: A Voyage of Discovery, Made Under the Orders of the Admiralty, in his Majesty's ships Isabella and Alexander for the purpose of exploring Baffin's Bay, and Enquiring into the possibility of a North-West Passage.
The White Cottage
bibl.note: Full title: The White Cottage. A Tale.. Mitford rated it too dismal.

bibl.title: Calamities of Authors
bibl.note: Full title: Calamities of Authors: including some inquiries respecting their moral and literary characters.

bibl.title: Observations on the Theory and Practice of Landscape Gardening
bibl.note: Full title: Observations on the Theory and Practice of Landscape Gardening: Including some remarks on Grecian and Gothic architecture, collected from various manuscripts, in the possession of the different noblemen and gentlemen, for whose use they were originally written; the whole tending to establish fixed principles in the respective arts.

bibl.title: Observations on the Nature and Tendency of the Doctrine of Mr. Hume, concerning the relation of cause and effect
A Visit to the Monastery of La Trappe, in 1817
bibl.note: Full title: A Visit to the Monastery of La Trappe in 1817 With Notes Taken During a Tour Through Le Perche, Normandy, Bretagne, Poitou, Anjou, Le Bocage, Touraine, Orleanois, and the Environs of Paris. Illustrated with Numerous Coloured Engravings, from Drawings Made on the Spot. Mitford records that she liked it very well.

bibl.title: A Chronological History of Voyages Into the Arctic Regions
bibl.note: Full title: A Chronological History of Voyages Into the Arctic Regions; Undertaken Chiefly for the Purpose of Discovering a North-East, North-West, or Polar Passage between the Atlantic and Pacific: From the Earliest Period of Scandinavian Navigation, to the departure of the Recent Expeditions, under the Orders of Captains Ross and Buchan.

bibl.title: A Picturesque Tour Through France, Switzerland, on the Banks of the Rhine, and Through Part of the Netherlands in the Year 1816
bibl.note: Mitford rated it as stupid.

bibl.title: Memoirs of the Legal, Literary, and Political Life of the Late, the Right Honourable John Philpot Curran
bibl.note: Full title: Memoirs of the Legal, Literary, and Political Life of the Late, the Right Honourable John Philpot Curran, Once Master of the Rolls in Ireland: comprising copious anecdotes of his wit and humour; and a selection of his poetry; interspersed with occasional biography of his distinguished contemporaries in the Senate and at the Bar. Mitford rates it as stupid.

bibl.title: A Circumstantial Narrative of the Campaign in Russia
bibl.note: 2 vols. Full title: A Circumstantial Narrative of the Campaign in Russia: embellished with plans of the battles of the Moskwa and Malo-Jaroslavitz: interspersed with faithful descriptions of those affecting and interesting scenes of which the author was an eye-witness.

bibl.title: A Year and a Day
bibl.note: 2 vols. Full title: A Year and a Day. A Novel. Written under the pseudonym Madame Panache. Mitford rates it pretty enough but too dismal. Source: Journal.

bibl.title: Mémoires Particuliers de la Captivité de la Famille Royale de la Tour de Temple
bibl.author: Marie-Thérèse Charlotte de France, Duchesse d'Angloulême
bibl.note: Full title: Mémoires particuliers, formant avec l'ouvrage de M. Hue et le Journal de Cléry l'histoire complète de la captivité de la famille royale de la Tour de Temple.

bibl.title: Woman, or Minor maxims
bibl.note: In 2 volumes. Full title: Woman, or Minor maxims. A Sketch. Minerva Press.

bibl.title: The Lives of Haydn and Mozart
bibl.author: L. A. C. Bombet
bibl.note: Full title: The Lives of Haydn and Mozart: With Observations on Metastasio, and on the Present State of Music in France and Italy.

bibl.title: Anecdotes of Distinguished Persons
bibl.author: William Seward
bibl.note: 4 vols. Full title: Anecdotes of Distinguished Persons: Chiefly of the Last and two preceding centuries. Adorned with sculptures. The second edition, with additions and corrections. Mitford called it very amusing. Source: Journal.

bibl.title: Anecdotes of the Manners and Customs of London from the Roman Invasion to the Year 1700
bibl.author: James Peller Malcolm

publisher.orgName: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, and Brown

bibl.note: Full title: Anecdotes of the Manners and Customs of London from the Roman Invasion to the Year 1700: including the origin of British society, customs and manners, with a general sketch of the state of religion, superstition, dresses and amusements of the citizens of London during that period: to which are added, illustrations of the changes in our language, literary customs, and gradual improvement in style and versification, and various particulars concerning public and private libraries: illustrated by eighteen engravings.

bibl.title: The Works of the Rt. Hon. Edmund Burke
bibl.author: Edmund Burke
bibl.note: The Rivingtons published a comprehensive edition of Burke's works and correspondence, including his unpublished manuscripts, between 1801 and 1823, based, in part, on an earlier 3-volume edition by Dodsley. Mitford calls Burke a sad turncoat. Source: Journal.

bibl.title: The Life of Burke
bibl.author: Robert Bisset
bibl.note: Full title: The Life of Edmund Burke: Comprehending an Impartial Account of his Literary and Political Efforts, and a Sketch of the Conduct and Character of his Most Eminent Associates, Coadjutors, and Opponents. Published in 1798 and 1800, this title was the most current biography of Burke available at the time of reading. James Prior would publish a more authoritative account in 1824 that superceded those by Bisset and MacCormick (1798).

bibl.title: A Narrative of the Expedition to Egypt
bibl.author: Robert T. Wilson
bibl.note: Full title: A Narrative of the Expedition to Egypt. Under Sir Ralph Abercrombie. Containing An Exposition of the Principles and Conduct of Napoleon Buonaparte. Abridged from the History of that Campaign. With Occasional Notes.

bibl.title: Lectures on Painting: Delivered at the Royal Academy, March, 1801.
Materials for Thinking
bibl.author: William Burdon

bibl.title: Account of the Extraordinary and Shocking Case of George Mathews
bibl.author: George Mathews
James Harner
bibl.note: Full title: Account of the Extraordinary and Shocking Case of George Mathews: Who was Capitally Convicted at the Old Bailey in February, 1818 on a False Charge of Robbing His Master, Colonel Whaley, and Afterwards, Through the Benevolent Influence of Mr. Alderman Wood, the Hon. Mr. Bennett and Others, Pardoned by the Prince Regent, on the Clearest Proofs Being Given of His Innocence : Containing a Report of the Trial of Mathews, a Sketch of His Life, His Memorial to the Prince Regent, Colonel Whaley's Answer, Remarks Thereon, and Mr. Harmer's Letter, Explaining His Reasons for Assisting in the Development, and Obtaining a Pardon for Mathews.

listBibl.bibl:
The Wonders of the Little World Nathaniel Wanley
London
Full title: Wonders of the Little World; or, a General History of Man: displaying the various facultires, capacitities, powers and defects of the human body and mind. In many thousand most interesting relations of persons remarkable for bodily prfections or defects; Collected from the writings of the most approved historians, philosophers, and physicians, of all ages and countries. Forming a complete system of the mental and corporeal powers and defects of Human Nature. And intended to increase knowledge, to promote virtue, to discourage vice, and furnish topics for innocent and ingenious converssation. Mitford may have read the 2-volume expanded edition published in 1806, edited my William Johnston.>

bibl.title: The Fall of Jerusalem
bibl.note: Full title: The Fall of Jerusalem: A Dramatic Poem.

bibl.title: Mansfield Park
bibl.note: 3 volumes. Full title: Mansfield Park: A Novel. Published as bu the Author of Pride and Prejudice.

bibl.title: Sense and Sensibility
bibl.note: 3 volumes. Published anonymously as by a Lady. Mitford rated it very good.

bibl.title: Memoirs of the Life and Writings of Sir Philip Sidney
bibl.note: Mitford rated it as stupid.

bibl.title: Popular Tales
bibl.note: In 3 volumes. Volume 1 includes: Lame Jervas, The Will, The Limerick Gloves, Out of Debt Out of Danger; Volume 2 includes: The lottery, Rosanna, Murad the Unlucky, The Manufacturers; Volume 3 included: The Contrast, The Grateful Negro, To-morrow.

bibl.title: Moral Tales for Young People
bibl.note: In 3 volumes. Includes: Forester, The Prussian Vase, The Knapsack, The Good Aunt, The Good French Governess, Mademoiselle Panache and Angelina; or, L'Amie Inconnue.

bibl.title: Comic Dramas, in Three Acts
bibl.note: Contains three plays: Love and Law; The Two Guardians; and The Rose, Thistle and Shamrock. Mitford rated them not good.

bibl.title: Letters from the Hon. Horace Walpole, to the Rev. William Cole and others
bibl.note: Full title: Letters from the Hon. Horace Walpole, to the Rev. William Cole and others, Esq. from the year 1736, to the year 1770: Now First Published from the Originals. Mitford called them delightful.

bibl.title: Mystery, or Forty Years Ago: A Novel
bibl.publisher: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, and Brown
bibl.note: 3 vols. Mitford considered it not very good.

bibl.title: Altham and His Wife: A Domestic Tale
bibl.note: 1 vol. Mitford calls it a pretty tale. Source: Journal

bibl.title: Memoirs of the Life of Peter Daniel Huet, Bishop of Avranches
bibl.publisher: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, and Brown
bibl.note: 2 vols. Full title: Memoirs of the Life of Peter Daniel Huet, Bishop of Avranches, written by himself and translated from the original Latin, with copious notes, biographical and critical. Mitford calls them very entertaining. Source: Journal.

bibl.title: Memoirs of the Life of the Great Condé

author.persName: Louis Joseph de Bourbon, prince de Condé

bibl.note: Translated into English from the French by Fanny Holcroft. Mitford called them not very good and stupid enough. Source: Journal.

bibl.title: Display
bibl.note: Full title: Display: A Tale. For Young People.

bibl.title: The Vision; or, Hell, Purgatory, and Paradise
bibl.note: Printed for the author.

bibl.title: Letters from the North of Italy
bibl.note: 2 vols. Full title: Letters from the North of Italy: Addressed to Henry Hallam, Esq.. Mitford called it very good though vulgar.

bibl.title: The Quakers: A Tale
Specimens of the British Poets
bibl.note: 7 vols. The Essay on English Poetry which prefaces this collection, forms part of the controversy over the significance of Pope's works. Mitford records she likes it very much and that it is very good.

bibl.title: Les Parvenus; ou, Les Aventures de Julien Delmours
Zapolya
bibl.note: Subtitled: A Dramatic Poem ] . . .] in humble imitation of The Winter's Tale of Shakespeare. Mitford called it very good.

bibl.title: Memoirs of the Late Mrs. Elizabeth Hamilton
bibl.publisher: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, and Brown
bibl.note: 2 vols. Full title: Memoirs of the Late Mrs. Elizabeth Hamilton, with a selection from her correspondence and other unpublished writings. Mitford rated it very bad.

bibl.title: The Rivals: A Comedy
bibl.note: First performed in 1776 at Covent Garden Theatre. Upon reading the play, Mitford rated it famous.

bibl.title: Narrative of the Expedition which Sailed from England in 1817, to Join the South American Patriots
bibl.note: Full title: Narrative of the Expedition which Sailed from England in 1817, to Join the South American Patriots: Comprising Every Particular Connected with Its Formation, History, and Fate; with Observations and Authentic Information Elucidating the Real Character of the Contest, Mode of Warfare, State of the Armies, &c..

bibl.title: The History of Jenny Spinner
bibl.note: Full title: The History of Jenny Spinner, the Hertfordshire Ghost. Written by herself. Reprinted in Pall Mall magazine.
